<@U08KN6ZHC|elie> has joined the channel

hey everyone , since its my first app my question may sound dumb (but have to ask) , i just want to know if our  app is based on `android` and `iOS` both os so ,  do providing a taste of the native os in ui matters ? i started with iOS so i designed the `ui` in iOS first and now in android the ui is same as i have in `iOS`    they are almost same. so its not going to hurt anybody right ?
am asking this because i've seen same apps with different `ui` in different operating systems
the better your app caters to Android users, the better it will be received
Android and iOS apps should have their own UI but if you’re trying to do a minimum viable product, I guess you can stick with the same UI for both platforms until the MVP is complete
you don't have to update the UI, but people will most likely have a better experience if you do
can you please tell me what it , means  ?  `MVP is complete` <@U08KN6ZHC>
I personally dislike obvious iOS ports, makes it feel as if the Android app is an afterthought, and in most cases the quality of those apps is not good
<@U0JBN2DV2>: minimum viable product
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_viable_product>

It’s also a matter of what people are used to. Especially if you try to force navigation patterns of the other system to either Android or iOS users it won’t be well received. People expect at least some streamlined experience through out the phone.
iOS ports will mostly get you bad reviews, you won’t get installs and you lose any chance of getting featured

While a redundant back button might in most cases just give you an occational scoff, stuff like putting a nav bar on top of the android software navbar (back/home/recent) can cause accidental clicks/usually looks bad etc.
Yet Google is going this direction for two apps now. <https://twitter.com/lukew/status/705156719446351872>

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/lukew|@lukew>: yes, that’s a bottom navigation bar on two Android apps from Google. <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/Cck4TLfVAAAovrg.jpg>
attachments.text: yes, that’s a bottom navigation bar on two Android apps from Google. <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/Cck4TLfVAAAovrg.jpg>

i think as  we already have 3 buttons there (the home button and back button and last one i don't know what it is) so adding a new layer of buttons near them will going to give user a  not so simple ui experience , yeah as <@U04TK850N>  said until you have a bigger device with more room
I wouldn’t discard Google’s direction that fast. [Luke Wroblewski](<https://twitter.com/lukew>) was apparently involved in the project, and he’s quite the authority on interaction design.

attachments.title: Luke Wroblewski (@lukew) | Twitter
attachments.text: The latest Tweets from Luke Wroblewski (@lukew). Humanizing technology. Founded: Polar (Google acquired) Bagcheck (Twitter acquired) Wrote: Mobile First, Web Form Design, Site Seeing. Worked: Yahoo, eBay, NCSA. Silicon Valley

text: Top tab bars are nice, but only when you have swipeable tabs (because you don’t necessarily need to move your finger to the hard-to-reach parts of the screen).
Unfortunately, that makes using gestures in the tabs themselves rather difficult.
(like swiping aways cards or moving on a map)
On Hamburger menus, they are considered by most be an anti-pattern as they hide away parts of the interface. They should generally only contain less important things (settings, trash, etc.)
I really dislike how Google still promotes them so much.
Ultimately, it’s just lazy design.
It is a crutch that is used generally with conversations along the lines of “we have nowhere else to put it"

I say you should not try to achieve what you want.

And if you want it on a button you would do something like:

<android.support.v7.widget.AppCompatButton
                        android:layout_width="wrap_content"
                        android:layout_height="wrap_content"
                        android:drawableRight="@drawable/name_of_the_image/>

The carets are not meant to be used this way on Android. Why would you need to point a user to tap a list item if it’s a list item? Make sure you give proper feedback (changing the background colour) when a user taps the list item and he/she will understand that it’s clickable.

Hey guys! I'm PM at Zolt, a super tiny startup. We've made an app which is like a TL;DR for the news - it gives you short 60 word summaries of all the latest news in the form of a card stream. Each card has an image and some text below it. Currently, our font size for the text seems to be too big on some devices and if we reduce the font size, then it appears too small on some of the bigger devices. Trying to find some middle ground here. Any ideas?
how are you defining the font size

Also, we've received mixed feedback: some say that the image should be big, others say that the image needs to be smaller so that focus is more on the summary. Please check out the app from here: <https://goo.gl/cTvW0a>

text: fonts should be defined with SP, if you aren’t doing that then you will see variability
if that is not your issue then you should post in <#C04NZAN54> with a more specific issue
<@U055GGAHS>: Hey, we have defined the font with SP

There's another problem too. If the user changes his phone settings and makes the font size small, then app works fine. But if he makes the font size huge/large, then it disturbs the card layout entirely
correct

You usually just try to compensate as best as you can, users that set the fonts massive are generally used to that issue. Not saying its ok to make the content impossible to use but sometimes there isn’t a very good solution so you just try to make it work as best as possible.

Ladies and Gentleman, heres the deal: On the following scenario: a Fragment that uses both MVVM (Model-View-ViewModel) and the DataBinding framework.

I have a RecyclerView that has an Adapter for N ViewModels which hold an instance for the actual Model.

When I click on my View, through Databinding it reflects to my "startDownload" method on my ViewModel. Thats ok till now. My "startDownload" is called from the ViewModel, passing to the "doDownload" method my Model instance. How should I work here that, if my model changes (I'm downloading something so I want the totalDownloadedBytes to be refreshed), the ViewModel knows it and "notifyPropertyChanged" is called, so that the UI is actually according to my Model?
